awd_titl_txt: The Geometry of Measures and Analytic Properties of Associated Operators
awd_abstract_narration:
This project concerns a study of the some of the mathematics behind two basic physical questions.  The first question considered is to what extent can the geometry of a body be determined from information about a force field associated to the body (for instance its gravitational field)?  Such inverse problems in potential theory have a rich history, but the mathematical tools needed to answer this question are currently underdeveloped.  The investigation will focus especially on what can be said if one only knows that the field has bounded magnitude, which is of particular interest in applications.  A second question to be explored is how, and to what degree of accuracy, can one determine the asymptotic (or long term) behavior of a random function that evolves with time, based on certain empirical measurements?
 
More specifically, the principal investigator proposes to research several questions concerning the relationship between the geometrical properties of a measure and the regularity properties of an associated operator. The primary question of interest is the following: What can be deduced about a measure from the knowledge that singular integral operator associated to it has good regularity properties?  Under these circumstances, can the measure have a fractal structure, or must its support be contained in (a countable number of) Lipschitz sub-manifolds of appropriate dimension? Attempts to solve this problem has led to theory which has found recent applications in the calculus of variations, the study of free boundary problems, and the geometry of harmonic measure.  The principal investigator intends to further develop tools that serve as a bridge from the analytic condition on the singular integral operator to the geometric structure of the measure. A second topic of research concerns understanding the long-term behavior of a stationary Gaussian process given information about its spectral measure, building upon recent work involving the principal investigator.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The research lies at the interface of two subfields of mathematical analysis: geometric measure theory and harmonic analysis. 

A central object in geometric measure theory is the notion of (Hausdorff) dimension.  This notion of dimension recovers the intuitive idea that a line, or a circle, are both one-dimensional objects, but there are many other one dimensional objects such as the four corner Cantor set, formed via an iterative construction (see Figure 1).   A set need not have integer dimension; for instance the Von Koch snowflake shown in Figure 2 has dimension log 4/log 3.  

Geometric measure theory distinguishes between `nice' sets like lines or circles, and `rough' sets like the four corner Cantor set.  Broadly speaking, the notion of `nice' is usually understood analytically as being able to parametrize the set well, at which point one can introduce tools from calculus to further analyze the set.

  The basic problem of encountering a set and wanting to classify if it is `nice' or `rough' is fundamental:  it appears when one studies soap films (also known as minimal surfaces --  see, for instance in the work of Reifenberg, Almgren, and Taylor); when studying the shape of a jet of fuel emerging from a nozzle (the work Atl-Cafferelli-Friedman; this is a prototypical example of a free boundary problem); or when studying a data cloud in high dimensions, in which case one wants to know if the data points cluster around a lower dimensional surface so that the data can be efficiently encoded by a smaller number of variables (see the work of Jones, David-Semmes, and Lerman).

As an outcome of the research project, the PI, in collaboration with X. Tolsa and M. Villa resolved an outstanding open problem in this field, typically attributed to L. Carleson, concerning a criteria for when a Jordan curve in the plane has a tangent at a given point (see Figure 3).  The result confirms a conjecture that had been open for over thirty years, and appeared in the Annals of Mathematics.

A Jordan curve is a set that can be drawn with a continuous motion of the hand (without taking the pen off the page) without intersections (except the start and end points may coincide).  Examples of Jordan curves include line segments and circles, but  a self-similar set such as the Cantor set appearing in Figure 1 can be contained in a Jordan curve.  The Von Kock snowflake (Figure 2) is another example of a Jordan curve, so they may have dimension greater than 1. In fact they may have positive area (the so-called Osgood curve).  Our theorem therefore provides a remarkable dimension reduction, as the set of tangent points is one-dimensional (and moreover is a `nice' one-dimensional set).

Other major outcomes of the project concern understanding when sets have nice structure (similar to having tangents) as a result of the behavior of an associated operator acting on that set. In this case the operators are given by what are known as singular integral operators -- classical objects that appear in analysis and partial differential equations.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2024
Modified by: Benjamin Jaye
